“Here I am, professor Schön.” I said. He was my forensic anthropology professor.

“Ok. Mr. Eiserberg, let’s start.” Today we were going to identify a skeleton. Several years ago, there was a genocide in my country, in revenge for our past tyranny. Now everything settled. The war ended, the war criminals executed, and it was our job to rebuild and rehabilitate everyone. And it was the time for forensic anthropologists, to give the fallen back their identities.

Lying on the steel working table was a dry skeleton excavated from a mass grave. Its color stained yellow, its texture rough, its size was thin. It was a female, so thin and young when she left us. Perhaps a girl at my age if she survived.

I recorded the data down in the utmost calmness and respect. The only reason those guys spared my life was that I am their diplomat’s son. I witnessed with my own eyes my whole neighborhood was wiped out. And for the professor, he went exile.

“Mr. Eiserberg, I think we can use the computer and scanner there to reconstruct her face.” Thank God who inspired people inventing such technology, we can add flesh and skin to the bones virtually. So that once we got the skull and proper information like age, race, and gender, we know how the deceased looked like.

I saw a familiar face on the screen. “Professor, I know her. She is Erika Ludwig, my high school love.” My heart cringed.

“I have never heard of you having a girlfriend.”

“Yes. Because I am waiting her.” Perhaps I should consider lifelong celibacy.

He gently patted my shoulder and continued completing our work. As the other identified victim, her name would be in the newspaper the next morning.

I know it is a bad habit to have coffee at night, but it is too unbearable. When had I seen her last?

When they occupied the city and arrested almost everyone, my family suggested I study at the university of them. I did. On the road between the campus and my flat, there was a concentration camp. I saw her. I couldn’t bear that sight. What the hell they used my fellow as slave labor and nurtured me as their elite student! It was winter, the snow was knee-deep, and she was so consumed and dressed thin.

I called her name, gave her all the snacks I carried, kissed her cool cheek, and hugged her in no time. She was so pale, light, and feeble, just like leaves at Autumn. Out of the mercy of God, the holes of the wire fence were large enough for our arms. What did they do to her? At least today I saw no fracture on her body but It is even worser. Instead of facing the full blast of such life, I would rather choose a violent end as some of my classmates did.

They spotted me. A decent half-blooded fellow who choose none of the finest damsels in the town and campus, but instead a belittled girl from a defeated nation in a labor camp. This enraged them.

As my punishment, I received a good caning and became an exile. I completed my study in foreign countries.

Have I cared? No. If there was something I must regret, I regretted I couldn’t comfort her more, because I was not careful enough not letting us being spotted. Oh, don’t talk to me about nations and countries, as a guy having double nationalities, I essentially commit treason the same moment I being patriotic.

Now…she was gone. If I was braver, then I might be gone with her. Why I would practice my body, being so strong that I survived their caning? Why I was at my home when they drove my neighbors like a herd to the slaughterhouse? Then I would go with her… no, I actually did; we were on the same train, to different destinies!

I felt an urge to end my own life. The church preached it is an utmost sin. However, shouldn’t I die, as I’ve done nothing in the demise of my lover? Now what she remained here were some bones. I was too useless. Furthermore, half of me belonged to the kind that made her suffered to death. Storm in the gate of death and find her, then spend the entire eternity with her, saying “I love you.”, comfort her with all I might have in her last days, that I failed to give in my earthly time, that’s my plan.

“God, forgive me for this. What I plead now, is bring me to her, and please be gentle, I commit my soul.” I prayed, take out a full bottle of painkillers from my first aid box. Before I lied down on the bed, I curl and hug a teddy bear. It felt incredibly good, just like someone who understands is cuddling me warmly and gently. Who can stand in such a world with his love murdered in such a way and he even can’t help at all? At least, not me…

“Mr. Eiserberg, sounds like your pastor preaching is not good enough.” Said professor Schön. I found myself in the hospital.

“Why…” I burst out in tears. “I’ve lived long enough already.” I wept.

“No, you don’t. Firstly, to your standard, everybody here should have died already; you are just having your fair share of the pain of humanity, be a man. Secondly, I think you have a reason not to do suicide now.” He proclaimed, offered me a sandwich.

“What?”

“Half hour before, miss Ludwig has a phone call to the press. She is ALIVE.”

“Man, are you kidding me? Now I want to be alive and healthy! But there are so many people called “Erika” or surnamed “Ludwig”!” I couldn’t believe my ears. She is alive? What? But how about those bones, that yesterday I dearly cherished? Whose they belonged to?

“A professor tries his best not to joke in his career. Oops, I forget that your doctor forbids you from consuming ham and cheese, so stop munching your sandwich now.” He answered. His tone was always as calm as a cucumber.

“Ask her if she knows me, please! Now I want to live! Yes, please! My full name is Gilbert Moinen Eiserberg. Ask her!” I cried.

Then I spent my day with unspeakable joy and hope. Dear…I wished I could marry her in no time, I will take care of her lifelong with all my might. Poor girl, she must be heartbroken.

In the morning, Professor Schön came with my doctor. “Well, miss Ludwig does know you. But your doctor told me the bad news.”

“What?”

“Because of your suicide attempt, your kidneys are badly damaged enough that your remaining life is in months, and currently we have no donors.”

“How about the skeleton?”

“Last night our technician just discover an error in the data of the thickness of facial muscle, it is a bug and we have got a false result."
